text: when I look to the future I see both
really positive aspects and negative
aspects I see being able to understand
much more about other people and this
can be good at both in the business and
in a marketing context but I also see
the potential for lots of abuse where
businesses can understand too much about
us and our data can get out of control
my background is in human-computer
interaction so I've always been
interested in how people work with
computers when you add people to the mix
it gets much more complicated much more
messy but but much more interesting as
well what we found is that while there's
a lot of work being done on
understanding sentiment and aggregate
opinions from social media there was
very little work done really
understanding individuals at a deep
level so that is the direction that
we've been heading in modeling
understanding individuals so that
marketers could approach them in the
right way direct marketing in the United
States in 2012 companies spent 170
billion dollars on marketing and yet the
response rate is only about two percent
maybe a little bit more for direct mail
a lot less for online marketing so that
means that companies are spending 165
billion dollars sending people messages
that they don't want to receive and so
this money could be spent a whole lot
better the people could get a whole lot
less annoyed by all these messages that
are coming at them if they could just be
directed better if the messages could be
more relevant that if instead of
receiving 10,000 advertising contacts a
month maybe you've received 100 but they
really be relevant to who you are and
the kinds of things that you're
interested in our research got inspired
by a lot of work that comes out of the
psychology community what the
psychologists found is that the types of
language that that people use reflects
their person
all day so the kinds of words how often
you use the first-person pronouns versus
second person pronouns words about food
words about work all of these are
reflect your underlying personality and
what I found is looking at Twitter Pete
you do not need a very large sample of
Twitter tweets to get a fairly stable
measure of their language use so that
with a hundred tweets you can get say on
average plus or minus ten percent of the
measurements of how they're using
language as you would if you had a
thousand tweets and so once you have
that language we have various models
that we are continually building
evolving for measuring personality how
you interact with the world and this
includes traits such as extraversion are
you an extrovert are you introvert
conscientiousness how organized and
hardworking are you agreeable pneus are
you easygoing are you uptight
neuroticism which always gets a laugh
but the psychologists use eroticism is a
way of describing emotional stability
how prone are you to negative emotions
so all these different types of
personality to vent dimensions which are
all really kind of relevant in the
marketing context now if somebody is
prone to negative emotions in your
marketing message you want to be
reassuring if somebody is not from the
negative emotions then perhaps you can
talk you can stress the features how
many different things you can do with
whatever you're selling every time I
talk about this in public people react
sort of a little bit viscerally there I
mean it can be creepy all the different
kinds of things that you can understand
from somebody's linguistic footprints
their their behavioral footprints online
and they start to think oh well maybe I
should be changing my privacy settings
and the default privacy settings on
Twitter is that anybody in the world can
read what you're doing and for me in
just the pure scientific pursuit of
understanding this is wonderful because
I all this data that I can just get at
and that I can really understand how

if they realized all the things that
